wordpressPost.title: 5 Employee Engagement Truths About Millennials
wordpressPost.content:
Millennials, also known as Gen Y, now make up about 25% of the global workforce, according to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics. With this new generation comes a new employee mindset that employers will need to understand to maximize productivity and innovation, while avoiding the cost of high turnover rates.

Here are 5 important facts every manager and C-Suite executive should know as they prepare to engage this new workforce:

1. Millennials are the future.

By 2020, millennials will form 50% of the global workforce, and according to Millennial Branding, In 2025, that number balloons to 75%.

2. Millennial employee retention is tough.

Millennial Branding also claims that more than 60% of millennials leave their company in less than three years. They call this a very expensive revolving door.

3. They’re expensive to replace.

A 2013 study entitled The Cost of Millennial Retention, found that 87% of companies reported it costs between $15,000 and $25,000 to replace each millennial employee they lose.

Furthermore, 56% of employers revealed that it takes between 3 – 7 weeks to hire a fully productive millennial in a new role and 51% said the cost of training and development is the highest when hiring millennials, emphasizing the importance of millennial employee retention.

4. Corporate social responsibility and sustainability is key to keeping them around.

A recent report by PwC found that 58% of millennials said they would avoid working in a particular sector solely because they believe it had a negative image. The same report found that 56% said they would consider leaving an employer who no longer met their expectations.

Deloitte’s The Millennial Survey 2014, found that millennials think business can do much more to address resource scarcity (68%), climate change (65%) and income equality (64%). And half of the millennials surveyed said they want to work for a business with ethical practices.

In 2014, WeSpire’s The State of Employee Engagement in Sustainability & CSR found that 55% of millennials surveyed said they would like to see their employer change their stance on employee sustainability efforts moving forward.

5. They want to engage their coworkers.

According to a survey done by PGI, 71% of employees said they wanted their co-workers to be a second family.

According to WeSpire’s report, The State of Employee Engagement in Sustainability and CSR, 75% of millennials are interested in the sustainability efforts of their coworkers and employer.

How is your company preparing for the increasing influx of millennials? Is this new generation of workers a concern of yours?
